who uses special “boxes” measuring “color” and “hardness” instead of Du Bois magnets measuring spin in different directions. Examples of modern physics textbooks taking this approach are Sakurai & Napolitano (2017
who, like Hughes, cites The Feynman Lectures and Sakurai as his inspiration for this approach (ibid

title: A Du Bois magnet is a ring or half-ring magnet used to produce intense inhomogeneous magnetic fields
Du Bois, a Dutch applied physicist known for his work in electromagnetism and optics
and for his book, The Magnetic Circuit in Theory and Practice

Variations on the Stern-Gerlach experiment, in which particles are sent through multiple Du Bois magnets with axes pointing in different directions before being made to impact on a screen (see Eisberg & Resnick

have been used many times before, by philosophers and textbook writers alike, to introduce the counterintuitive nature of quantum mechanics. Two well-known examples from the philosophy of quantum mechanics literature are Hughes (1989, Introduction
